com:
Hi, anyone know how to use ffmpeg on raspian to record video from a webcam and audio from an usb microphone?
The webcam is a PiCamera that support 1920x1080 resolution

if i execute this command:
ffmpeg -f v4l2 -framerate 23 -video_size 640x480 -i /dev/video0 -f alsa -i plughw:1 output.mp4
everything works fine

if i increase the quality like this:
ffmpeg -f v4l2 -framerate 23 -video_size 1280x720 -i /dev/video0 -f alsa -i plughw:1 output.mp4
the video is very laggy with almost no audio

if i increase to the max:
ffmpeg -f v4l2 -framerate 23 -video_size 1920x1080 -i /dev/video0 -f alsa -i plughw:1 output.mp4
then it doesn't even start and give this error:

[video4linux2,v4l2 @ 0x20e6280] ioctl(VIDIOC_STREAMON): Operation not permitted
/dev/video0: Operation not permitted

Am i stuck at 640x480 or can i do something?
Pic unrelated.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
OP here again, is very late so i will check the replies tomorrow.
So sorry if i don't reply right away.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
Compressing FullHD isn't easy for little processors and realtime compression like you're asking for is not likely to happen.

Test encoding as mjpeg which has much lower cpu requirements. The cost of low cpu is much more storage space and much more bandwidth if transmitting the stream. You can recompress it later if you need to and at least there's something to recompress which is better than not even capturing a stream in the first place.

name: fuwafuwa kemono
com:
posted this on lit before but i want to get more opinions:
i got a more than 100 years old series of books on german literature history and they might be the most beautiful and well-designed books i ever had the plesure of owning...
the problems is that they have some weird spots – some dark and some brown – so i wanted to know if this looks like normal, age-related foxing, just some dust or possibly (harmful) mold
i also know that mold is everywhere but my worry would be the extreme kind of mold which would spread and ruin a collection

1. it didn't really have a strong smell i would say
2. i managed to get a bit off with a cotton swab and made a new picture (the one on the right)
i could theoretically send it back but it's in quite good quality so i would only do so if it is really the bad kind of mold

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1292633
The pale spots at the left look like foxing.

The dark stuff in the middle doesn't look like foxing and foxing can't be wiped off with cotton swabs anyway so it's not foxing. Looks more like mildew than mould. That the odl book smell is not strong doesn't mean it's not mildew, only that there's not enough mildew to make it smell strongly. If it was powdery or flaked off, almost certainly mildew since what we call mould is slimy or fuzzy not flaky.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
Try podcasts and YouTube. Easy, digestible and mostly informative. It's also how pretty much 90% of /his/ retards get their history (unless they're /pol/-brained schizos who get it all from stormfag memes).

Dan Carlin's Hardcore History is the classic, but it's kinda dumb /pw/-guy territory. To be fair, if you're an uneducated oaf that is probably what you want.

Mike Duncan had two very good podcasts: History of Rome chronologically covered the entire history of Rome from founding of the city to collapse of the Western Empire (early episodes are very rough audio quality wise, but it gets better).
The second is Revolutions, which is a collection of narratives on famous political revolutions, from the English Civil War to the American Revolution, French Revolution, Haitian Revolution and all the way to the Russian Revolution(s). It's pretty much a crash course in early modern European political history.

Beyond that you can just google literally any country, civilization or era and add "history podcast" to that and get sometimes multiple hits. My personal favorite is History in the Bible, but that's kinda niche.

On YouTube it's mostly garbage, but you can look up whatever you want and the Algorithm will happily dump some 95 IQ normalfag shit (which, again, is probably what you want). History Matters is the least worst one.

My personal YouTube "favorites" are Historia Civilis, Jeffrey the Librarian and Religion for Breakfast.

Finally you should look up the bibliography of any pop-history internet thing you consume. Any responsible channel or podcast should have a section like that. Pick out a book that looks particularly interesting to you and pirate it. As long as it's not an unbearable academic slog, it should be a good entry point to actual history. Wikipedia citations work similarly.

Generated by AI:

>The tragedy of Hamlet is a story about a young prince who is seeking for revenge for the death of his father. It is well known that early on in the play, a ghost appears to Hamlet and reveals the truth that his uncle, Claudius, had murdered his father. Despite this knowledge, however, it takes Hamlet a long time to act on this truth and seek out his vengeance. To further understand why it takes Hamlet so long to act, it is important to look at his background and story of self-discovery.

>First, it is important to understand that Hamlet is faced with a conflict within himself at the beginning of the play. On the one hand, he feels obligated to avenge his father’s death, as is expected of a prince. On the other hand, Hamlet struggles with his conscience, as he does not wish to murder his uncle. The moral dilemma that Hamlet faces weighs heavy on his decision to seek revenge, thus it automatically slows down his progress. Moreover, Hamlet is unsure if the ghost’s information is accurate and does not want to take any risks if it is not. This second dilemma, however, is only so much of a factor because the ghost proves to be credible.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>Hamlet must also face a series of life events that further complicate his pursuit of revenge. His time away at school leaves him feeling overwhelmed and disconnected from his home and the circumstances surrounding his father’s death. Upon his return, Hamlet must navigate the politics of Denmark which are now dominated by his uncle’s suspicious behavior. In addition, Hamlet must face his mother and his love of his former childhood with Ophelia. Although they all have a degree of influence on his delay of revenge, Hamlet’s most difficult battle is with himself. He is debating back and forth in his head, trying to overcome his moral dilemma and determine what action is necessary to properly avenge his father’s death. These inner feelings and struggles of self-reflection take the most time, and rightfully so, as this is the most important aspect for Hamlet.

>The tragedy of Hamlet illustrates a story in which the protagonist must face difficult inner and outer battles in order to make the proper decisions. Hamlet’s delay in seeking revenge is intertwined with his personal battle of morality and self-discovery. He must come to terms with his internal plight as well as the events around him before he is able to properly and accurately avenge his father’s death. Therefore, it takes Hamlet a long time to act on the truth he is given early on in the play.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: For those wondering, Yagyuu Hadaka Shinken is running in Shogakukan "Weekly Post" (not to be confused The Weekly Post). Since the series is physical-only, that means most of the series will require quite a bit of magazine hunting for those too impatient to see the whole series in tankōbon format. com:
hey anon !

I want to change my graphics card on my pc to put a new one,
do I need to change my motherboard or my cpu to upgrade my pc ?

My motherboard:
>pci express 3.0;
>model : a320m pro-e;
>chipset : amd, k15 imc

My cpu :
>AMD A8,
>socket am4

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1292396
>4%
That's not even what the graphic you cherry-picked from google says.
But anyways, that chart's talking about running a x16/3.0 GPU on fewer/slower lanes, whereas I'm talking about running the new wave of x8-only/4.0 budget GPUs on x8/3.0, which they're not designed to do and will run like dogshit.

>Higher resolution textures and other data mean the GPU has to access information over the PCIe interface more often, and with an x8 PCI 3.0 interface that appears to be a problem in quite a few games. The 12900K is 20% faster [than 9900K] at 1080p ultra overall, with Forza Horizon 5 showing a 40% improvement and Red Dead Redemption 2 running 71% faster.
https://www.tomshardware.com/reviews/intel-arc-a380-review/4

Budget GPUs with tiny dies and fewer PHYs are coming, and Arc A3 is the bellwether. x8/3.0 is simply not fast enough for a budget GPU, though somewhat perversely it's probably fine for a mid/high GPU with a load of RAM. You're probably going to see a low-end 8x00 with 4.0/x8 and a small amount of VRAM stacked on top of the die, this would be super cheap to manufacture, and there'd be significant savings on the die footprint (and therefore the yield) and also the board cost by not having to fit another 16 PHYs and 32 pins on the die.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
ok I understand, but I still have to stay on a small budget hoping that changing the motherboard will be a good investment in passing.

Besides, what do you think of this config? :

>AMD R5 4600G
>Gigabyte B550M DS3H
>4 GB GDDR6 - HDMI/DisplayPort - PCI Express (AMD Radeon RX 6400)

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1292408
I would keep the old motherboard and get a 6600 GPU. B550 does bring some advantages, mainly NVMe, but you will see more advantage from a GPU that's twice as fast.

If you're not familiar with pcpartpicker, click this link, then (if you're not in the USA) click the person icon, and select the country you're in. It'll find you good deals on whatever's available where you are. That link specifically will find you "a 6600" and "the cheapest modern AMD 6-core processor that's not low-power and is compatible with your board".

You should be able to fit the graphics card and CPU without removing anything else; make sure your PSU has a graphics card (sometimes labelled "PCIe") power connector.

name: Anonymous
com:
How do I make a certificate on my Apache server so that only software that I've made can access it?

I made a program (like Kiwix) that fetches data from my server but I dont want people accessing that data using Firefox or anything.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1292323
- generate CA certificate
- generate x509 client certificate(s)
- sign x509 certificates with CA
- install CA public key on Apache machine
- install client certificates in your user-agent (check the documentation for whatever library makes your HTTP requests)
- configure Apache with mod_ssl and Require ssl-verify-client
- check SSL_CLIENT_WHATEVER in $SERVER[] if you need to tell specific certificates apart
- take whatever precautions are required to keep private keys safe (CA key should be stored offline and used with offline hardware, i.e. a raspberry pi with a monitor and keyboard and no internet connection, certificates should be transported by sneakernet), client certificates should be protected from other computers by the OS (Bitlocker, NTFS encryption, correct ACLs and so on).

name: Anonymous
com:
Hello, I need help with factoring some functions.
I have some limits that have a 0/0 indetermination, and the higher grade is 5 for the one I'm trying to solve. I tried to apply ruffini to factorize it as I've been thaught, using the limit as the first root (as I know it gives 0). But afterwards, no possible root at all worked.


The equation is this one:
x^5-2x^3+4x^2-10x-12
That would be the upper term. The limit was 2, so that was the first root, but afterwards it followed:
(1x^4+2x^3+2x^2+8x+6).(x-2)
And no possible root appears to work, or I couldn't solve them.
Possible roots from gauss would be, I think = +-(12, 6 ,4, 3, 1, 2)
I couldn't solve with any after 2.


I'd really appreciate if anyone could show how do you factorise it using ruffini, as to see where I'm going wrong.
Seeing a graph online, it seems -2 and some number among 0 and -1.
I'm also wondering why that negative decimal isn't among possible roots.

This is the full limit function, in case:
(x^5-2x^3+4x^2-10x-12)
/
(3x^4 - x^3 - 9x^2 - 4)


Thanks beforehand for any help

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1292121
>I'd really appreciate if anyone could show how do you factorise it using ruffini,

You don't.

>as to see where I'm going wrong.

You're going wrong by trying to use the method of Ruffini. You and I both get

y = (x-2)(x^4 + 2x^3 +2x^2 + 8x + 6)

but that quartic has only two real roots both of which are irrational, and the other two are imaginary roots of the form x = a + bi where both a and b are irrational. You can't factorise that equation with Ruffini.

The approximate roots are x ∈ {-2.2, -0.8, 0.5 + 1.7i, 0.5 - 1.7i} and the exact root is x = 2.

If you sketched the graph, y=x^5-2x^3+4x^2-10x-12 or at least found the positions where dy/dx = 0 you would have determined that it has only two turning points. As it is a quintic this would instantly tell you it has at most three real roots and possibly only one real root making Ruffini a poor choice.

last_replies.name: Anonymous

>>1292199

I've been solving a few limits.

What I got to see is that the common factor to remove, when possible, many times comes from the common root of the value at which x tends. So normally it wouldn't be necessary to try to factorise any further. And in some cases, it seems it isn't correct to do it. Thanks again.

>If you sketched the graph, y=x^5-2x^3+4x^2-10x-12 or at least found the positions where dy/dx = 0 you would have determined that it has only two turning points.
